review_title: How are we doing at IBM
pros: I would give 4.5 stars but can only give whole starts. I don't think IBM is perfect but I'm not either. There is great opportunity within IBM.. Many training environments and opportunities to keep us fulfilled with expanding our roles here with diversity, new process and quantum computing. The list is almost limitless.
cons:
Too much is shared on slack, it seems it an open book but do get many responders to find answers to many open questions. 

There is better hiring now but ran too lean and mean for too many years>
With experienced IBM'ers leaving for brand new ones out of graduate school. There is not any good cross over to that dump some of that experience to transition to the new people. Wish there was a better way but with 2 weeks notice can't get anybody hired before the person leaves. Not going to close that gap anytime soon.

job_title: Software Engineer in Foster City, CA
pros:
· Classic tech company amenities: free coffee, snacks, drinks.
· The majority of coworkers are nice and friendly. The camaraderie was the highlight of my experience.
· Huge bell curve. Top engineers there are brilliant, but the worst ones are unmotivated and coasting. Frankly, the average engineer is nothing to sneeze at.
· If you want to coast, a good place to do it. 
· There are opportunities to work hard and make an impact.
cons:
· Pay is not competitive for the location. Lowball. 
· Bad apples. While they exist in every workplace, their existence speaks to the company's culture and behavioral hiring bar. HR is unhelpful and won't protect one from harassers. 
· Management lacks structure with task assignments and does not keep promises. Politics get in the way of good work. 
· Lack of formal structure because the place is small. There's no formal way to keep track of tasks.
· Mediocre engineering standards. Not much of a formal code review process and poor code quality.

review_title: Fixing the door whilst the house is burning
pros: Base Pay is not bad though bonus scheme is farce. Nice enough colleagues. Training system is very good, but when you actually seek resource to go and win some business its not available and the process is dire.
cons: Leadership have clearly lost the plot, obsessed with trying to push Hybrid Cloud when the horse has bolted and already several valleys away with hyperscale providers. Internal process is shocking using lotus notes and Atlas, having to use a password t log in repeatedly to the same applications. Internal sales process is painful and the admin cost to get any sale out of the door is a joke. Not prepared to take people of fee earning work to develop decent bids so you end up with a bench of staff not skilled in the areas you actually need, so you lose the bid. No competitive targets being hit because of this as the A Team is never available and at best you get the C or D team. Management obsess about the current QTR whilst walking towards a cliff edge as no new work being won, But most don't care as will move on promotion or retire with bonus from core work. More obsessed with measuring diversity than addressing the real problems that need real investment like decent CRM and basic email system that works.

review_title: IBM Solutions Delivery, Inc. (Philippines) - Fresh Graduate (2020)
pros:
- Certifications. You can take free certifications here whether it is cloud related or whatnot.
- Learning resources. You have free Udemy and internal IBM Learning Resource.
- Experience working with known companies.
- Free covid-19 vaccination.
- Brand (IBM is a well known company)
cons:
- Salary. This must be the lowest one when compared to its competitors.
- Benefits. Still, not even close to its competitors.
- Higher Management. You know there is a big problem when a fresh graduate felt that there's something wrong.
- Incentives. Non-existent (maybe depends on project)
- Bootcamp. Not that extensive when compared to other companies.
- Known / Big companies are not for fresh graduates. If you have a career path that you want to pursue, never ever apply to big companies who doesn't put what you're going to work on specifically (fullstack development, mobile development, analyst, etc.). Even though you're the top of the class during bootcamp, that doesn't matter at all because they will give you a random role. More than likely, you'll get a support role (ticketing, monitoring, and excel).
- Covid19 response. We passed bootcamp in March 2020, we were deployed in September 2020.

I declined numerous offers between March 2020 to September 2020 with the role that I want because I trusted IBM. I took my internship here (which is miles ahead compared to my current work) and applied here. I didn't expect this from IBM. Its like they didn't even took a glimpse at your resume. Not recommended unless you don't have a career path planned ahead.

pros: Medical benefits are great. The projects that I've worked on have been engaging and interesting for the most part. Usually it's contracting work for companies outside of IBM. I have heard of some people getting stuck on projects that are not quite as glamorous though.
cons:
Before covid, it was mandatory to work in the office. This was frustrating because I was usually working with client teams in another state or country meaning I traveled all the way to the office to talk on the phone all day to talk to people that were nowhere near me.

The company is rather bureaucratic and there are a lot of hoops and seemingly unnecessary trainings that are required to move up the ranks.

The pay is pretty underwhelming given the average salary of the field. This was my first major job and I would say it's a great first job, but it feels like a stepping stone, not a destination.

job_title: Managing Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Working at IBM you're always (if you're in the right group) surrounded by smart people who can teach you a lot - about tech, running projects, and turning projects around. The WLB is also good, and direct management definitely seems to care about you as a person.
cons: There is a culture of mediocrity (slow and steady would be the nicer way to put it), that seems leftover from the old days when 30 years at IBM guaranteed you a full pension. For the most part, managers seem surprised when you ask what it takes to get promoted quickly. It's hard to get straight answers, and frequently the manager who gave you advice winds up leaving by the time they suggested you get promoted.

review_title: Good fast-paced ethical place to work, but...
pros:
• Extremely ethical company that really does care about doing good, the right and honest way.
• Such a massive team worldwide that you're always meeting new colleagues and having the chance to work with diverse teams across the globe.
• Immense learning experience and they invest heavily in learning materials to bring you up to speed (although a lot relies on your own curiosity as well).
• Almost everyone at IBM has been pleasant, professional, and always ready to help each other out.
• IBM isn't afraid to pivot its business operations in a moments notice if it feels that will be best for customers and for the business. 
• Salaries are decent.
cons:
• The company reinvents itself almost too often which leaves one feeling inadequately informed and has to rush to learn new techniques and methods to catch up and service clients. 
• Line managers are so busy with their own day-to-day that they tend to be too overwhelmed to provide support where/when needed. 
• Getting official approvals within the company is daunting. A 5-min job can take weeks to receive authorization, with much back and forth in between.
• Zero company culture. Extremely minimal (if any) fun social gatherings/events - even pre-Covid times. 
• Very poor pantry offerings.

pros:

cons: Was very frustrating to work for a pessimistic management heavy dinosaur with its unhealthy focus on squeezing as much money as possible from existing customer ELA agreements (IBM's legal red tape is second to none). review_title: Good work-life balance but lack of career growth opportunity...
pros:
1. Good Work-life balance. The organization culture promotes "trust" among employers and employees. These are much better compared to any peer Indian IT Service organizations.

2. Excellent learning culture. The organization provides and promotes (including financial support) for learning and growth (including external learnings) for individuals. There are many facilities to upskill and upgrade. Any proactive individual can easily utilize these opportunities to upgrade him/herself. (Most of the cases - organization assistances are no strings attached like 'approval only when a customer wants' which is stickily followed by many other Indian IT Service Organizations)

3. Promotes diversity in a big way. This organization is very good for woman employees as many of its policies and approach are favorable to them. 

4. This is an organization where people stay longer. (specially for those who love to be in a comfort zone)
cons:
1. Lack of Growth for an individual career. Management does not promote a growth mindset. The compensation and yearly hikes are much lesser compared to the market standard. The management encourages mediocrity. This results in a lack of innovation and agility. (though the organization claims otherwise in 'talks')

2. Top heavy organization and incompetent management. Processes are highly bureaucratic, slow, and complex. Too many hierarchies. Everyone seems to be highly insecure and lacks the courage and conviction to make the right decision on the top. CxO level strategy changes too frequently.

3. Most pathetic medical insurance for Indian employees especially if anyone has aged-dependent parents to take care of. (compared to medical insurance provided by other Indian employers)
